Strengths include quizzes and the book, which helped to emphasize key concepts. Weaknesses was not learning R properly and having to learn while doing lab work.

Strengths are that the course integrated R. Weaknesses are that the integration wasn't done extremely well and also that the course didn't seem to have as much structure as the other courses. We weren't given slides until the end of the semester and the information didn't flow well.

Clearer exam structure and expectations from the onset of the course
Having mandatory homework that is designed specifically for R as well as mandatory homework specifically conceptual.
Less restructuring of the course over the duration (though it was based on ongoing critique, it was personally very confusing and hard to keep track of what was going to be dropped, what exams would look like, etc)
Consistency of quizzes--are they extra credit, take home, or in class?

Course needed some background information in R or needs to be slowed down. The instructor had to teach too many things within a short amount of time. Split the course into Biostats and R or make it more cohesive by adding time to the course.
Good

Strengths: Learn R which is very useful and labs were very useful.
Weaknesses: I felt the class was not organized well. Learning R and stats at the same time is difficult but I think the stats should come before the R. I felt like we were taught R well but not stats at all. The lectures were super disorganized and we would just go over the lecture notes which we could easily read in our own time. A better use of lecture would have been to actually learn statistics. Like going over material in the readings, not referring to page numbers in the text book.

I personally think that the first topics could have been gone through faster, and focusing more in R teaching. (mean, median, and other basic stat concepts)
While some concepts as specific tests and the last part of the course, should be explained better and spend more time on that.
Some questions were too specific (and in my personal opinion, worthless to test in), while biggest concepts and ideas were not tested at all.
In the first classes, I wish the professor would have explained more of R rather than easy and basic concepts (that can be review in the TFs sessions).
Would prefer to have a smaller class.
Would prefer to have a summer or previous package for helping people learn some things before coming here.
Would prefer to take a short test to divide classes and sections according to level of previous knowledge.
need for improvement on what is relevant vs. not.
I feel that I learned a lot from this course and felt that it was a valuable addition to my education at YSPH.

While I think that Prof. Wininger genuinely cared about the class, the teaching style that he used was totally not useful to me. Instead of reviewing the material from the book in his own words to reinforce the ideas in a new way, he would just copy straight from the book. He also would not teach a lot of the material, he would just put it up on the board in his notes and then circle things that were hard to see even sitting very close to the front of the room. He rarely did out examples full examples in class, which are very useful for understanding material like statistics. This class was mostly about teaching yourself the material outside of class. I would often go to class hoping to gain a better understanding of what I had read in the book, but I would leave with no more knowledge than I came in with.

I think that he relied too heavily on the book and used it somewhat like a crutch.
Good course, definitely learned R and statistics.

No major points. I think it might be an interesting idea next year to assess student familiarity with course content via self-report or a short skill assessment before school. Then put students of similar skill level in the same section. This would allow more targeted teaching during the sections to different groups of students. It is very challenging to teach this content to multiple levels.

I feel that this class should be far smaller. There were too many people in the class for it to be productive. Also I think that R and stats should have been taught separately, or have had the labs specifically to teach us R. I think having an R practicum would have been more efficient than having us write code on the exams.

good. require self-study. More structured lectures.
would suggest a smaller class, or stratify into different levels based on maths and statistics ability.

Overall, this course was very poorly structured.  The exams were inconsistent with class material and were significantly harder than any homework or assignments we may have gotten in class.  We had three different exams, aside from the final, and each exam was set up differently.  I understand that he was a new professor and was trying out different exam styles, but it was not fair to the students.  The TFs had to teach us R entirely by themselves during lab where they would often get frustrated (completely understandable) that we would all come in knowing absolutely nothing.
Overall, I think this was a very good, thoughtful course.

This is the worst course I have ever taken in my entire life. It is hard to express how much stress it gave me, unnecessarily. Math isnt really my thing, but I came into this course with a positive attitude. I couldnt believe how demoralizing and simultaneously useless this course was. Let me break down what could be improved:

1. This was NOT designed as a core class. As a health policy student, I DID want to learn bio stats, because statistics can be really useful in policy, but in a broad way. It was impossible to get the main concepts out of this class with the lack of organization. It could be useful if it were more like  okay, heres an issue, here are the 3 things you would do/think as a public health professional if you see this. Instead he answered every q and proposed every topic as if we were in training to become statisticians. We, mostly, are not. All of the bio stats students arent even in our class. 

2.I left every lab for the first two months (and some towards the end) with a racing heart and cold sweats. WHY is this such a common things my friends and I experienced. I arrived to my first lab section and the tf (and mike!?!) expected me to just open up r and get some results. WHAT? I didnt even know whAt command prompt or r script is. To me, this is an unacceptable level of negligence, considering they quizzed us in the beginning of class so must have known some of us have never opened r in our lives. I dont think we should have had to learn it over the summer. I DO think there needed to be an intro class that was actually Taught!!! This could be way better if we worked over a longer period of time, maybe on more in depth projects that lasted a month or so.

3. Noooo coordination of tfs. Some (okay, just one...) were excelllent teachers, others thought of themselves more as babysitters with advanced r knowledge. Mike supported this variation for some reason. 

4. The sheer amount of documents posted is unwieldy and it is impossible to actually keep up with this course. The homeworks are NOT useful learning tools. WTF are 13 page homeworks where new r code is introduced in every problems answer code. So if youre introducing new concepts in an answer key, thats not homework, its just a useless document that you will later unfairly test us on. I dont know anyone who found them helpful as written, though some found them useful to review the answers for. This was SO demoralizing, as it felt like there is always soooo much else out there to learn and Ive never really grasped anything. 

5. The assessments. Are. Ridiculous. We are tested on stray comments prof makes in class, they are for some reason all written like riddles, and I never once felt like I knew what the main concepts he was trying to test us on were. I got better at recognizing what random nonsense the professor will test us on, but not at actually learning. None of the above questions where we havent heard of the r code in some of the questions is just testing our guessing ability, not stats knowledge. Please do an assessment where you compare performance on these with how much people knew about stats before entering. 

6. I will review the lecture experience in the professor section, but spoiler alert: the lectures were useless.

Strengths = learning R, which is very helpful 
Weaknesses = In the beginning of the semester the class was very unorganized in terms of instruction. R was not taught well and I think the professor would learn from other computing professors in how to initially teach this material. A summer tutorial through an online teaching software would be helpful so students have some initial exposure to the software. For example, swirl stats is a great example. Also, there seems to be a lot of trick questions on exams that don't test your knowledge, but rather test how well you can read the professors mind.

I feel as though fairly basic and fundamental concepts and applications were made more complicated and difficult to learn than was necessary. I think lab primers could be distributed in advance of the class in order for students to truly gain critical skills in R.
It is a difficult course that should have been split into two: biostatistics and R.
Learned a lot

Strenghs: review the basic knowledge of statistics knowledge carefully and  thoroughly; teach students to use R and write simple codes.
Weaknesses: Maybe a little hard for people who don't have background knowledge and sometimes it's not easy to understand the line of thought in class.
The labs and lectures can be more organized

WOW, what a rollercoaster!!! Three major things I thought were very challenging: 1. The extra credit structure in the course. It wasn't until the last lecture that we realized the extra points could inflate lab/quiz grades to over 100%. Going through the course, extra credit was seen as a reward for students who were understanding course material, not as a help to students who were not doing well and really needed it. Left a large divide in the class with a perceived few number of students in the middle. Might reconsider this style? and 2. Document overload. Between study guides and homework, and answer and lecture slides and lecture notes and readings and primers and worksheet and and and it was sometimes hard to sift through. I found the documents that were easy for me to follow and the documents with little mistakes/missing information and went with those to study and supplement the course and it seemed to work out okay for me. 3. Test questions: I resolved to learn the material for the sake of learning it because thats why I decided to come to YSPH rather than to become proficient with R or biostats or even learning material to pass one of Winninger's mind game exams that was more like a word puzzle. Thankfully I did okay, but often left exams feeling completely defeated after spending hours studying and extra time outside of class to receive the grades I did.

I thoroughly enjoyed the course. The course was designed well to cover both coding in R and statistical concepts. it would have been nice to have a little more R coding in class and more time to do labs every week. It also would have been nice to have a smaller class size or a discussion session for small groups to meet with the instructor or a TF. Regardless though, Professor Wininger did an excellent job catering to the needs and demands of the students, adjusting his teaching style to make the class happier. Personally though, I enjoyed his original, organic, style of teaching. He went absolutely above and beyond to provide the class with the resources and materials to succeed in the course.
It provided a good foundation in statistics and also R.
This class was incredibly, poorly designed, and taught in a completely ineffective way.

I never say this lightly, but this class was one of the worst ones I have ever taken- 
the material wasn't very difficult and in fact it is critical for our knowledge as future epidemiologists, however, the way the class was structured, taught, and organized was utterly horrible and unfair to us. biostats is the foundation of our data analysis skills and it is really unfair that we did not get a chance to develop these skills in a strong manner, instead we had to suffer due to the organization of this course.
the whole structure of where we HAD to read the textbook before the class, else we would have no idea what the instructor was talking about, was difficult and seemed like we had to teach everything to ourselves before even coming to class. the instructor literally would never go over stuff or actually "teach" biostats- it was more summarizing the textbook with the assumption that we know what's happening. Biostats needs to be taught on a whiteboard with examples, not using an iPad where the font projected on the screen is 12p and not even visible from the back of the room.
the whole merging of biostats + R is a very good thing but was done in the worst possible manner- without even teaching us anything, a lot of material was usually just posted online for our discretion and labs were structured in a way where we worked with data-sets. I think the labs were the best part of the course, since it helped us work with real-life datasets and practically develop skills, however this was again contingent on the assumption that the student has gone over the material and taught themselves everything.
really unfair for some students who may not have any stats background- for me, i did come in with some experience but still struggled to understand the organization of this course. i hope the appropriate people decide to change things for new students next year.

I have mixed feelings about this course. I want to begin by saying Mike consistently went above and beyond, and his dedication to the course and his students could not have been more clear. I always felt comfortable asking for help, and I strongly believe that he wanted me to succeed . That being said, I struggled with the structure of the course and did not find it conducive to learning introductory biostatistics. Incorporating R, which is undoubtedly an important skill, distracted me from truly grasping basic principles, and I found myself at times trying to memorize R code as opposed to making sure I understood the concepts. I think this class would be best taught without an additionally language. Additionally, our textbook had no connection to R, but we were often asked to interpret book questions in R, which was a frustrating and timely exercise.

Labs: should not be timed.  I wouldve learned more from labs, if I could have sat with them and worked on them at my own pace.  Or with a group.  And then come together for help from a TA.  Dont grade them if its too hard to sort out integrity.  Labs were my least favorite part of my semester at YSPH because they were so unnecessarily stressful.  Its weird to be tested on R content using multiple choice. 
Exams: I did fine on them because I can memorize sentences from the book.  But that doesnt mean I understood it all.

The TAs for this course were overall a disgrace, with the exception of Savanah. They held office hours at inconvenient times, left their office hours early, couldnt speak English well enough to convey material, and expected us to know R with no introduction.  Other professors are crutched by a solid group of TAs...Mike didnt have that, and he was a new professor, so thats why there was so much angst.  Other classes have sections with TAs that ECHO course material that the professor teaches.  Dont get it with the professor? No big deal, you can learn it from your TA that week in an optional section.  But our TAs were too busy worrying about labs with us.

Proposal: 
-Labs happen, we get the lab ahead of time, and lab attendance is required.  Pass/Fail grading.
-Hire two more TAs, that dont do labs.  They hold optional sections each week to go over lecture content.  Review sessions.  Like every other class here!
-Keep exams focused on fundamental concepts and takeaways, not such granular details that I can memorize but dont even know what they mean. 4 exams is a good number.
-Make all quizzes practice only.

I think with it being a new course, there were some hiccups. I think it was too much content to be learning in one semester with trying to master the concepts and the R coding part of it too, especially for someone who had zero programming experience before. I think it was not set up in a way that fostered excelling for students-unless they had previous knowledge in biostats or programming.

This course was designed very poorly and I did not enjoy taking it. Professor Wininger is a very nice guy but is very bad at teaching. I had to teach myself everything in this course, which took up a lot of outside of classroom time.

I think a more thorough introduction to R would have been helpful. I feel that we were thrown into it during the labs and were not provided with a real introduction to the program. 
I had a major advantage having taken biostatistics before. I saw some of my peers struggling to understand biostatistics and R at the same time. It may be helpful to have some readings that are about R, or to use labs to go over any concerns we have with integrating the material and R.
Pretty good. The latter half was better and I will allow other students to share explicitly any changes needed as I was satisfied.

MW is a great person and clearly very invested in us learning, but the lectures were very disorganized. He got better after the mid-semester feedback, but I still had a hard time seeing the point sometimes. I think the second module was particularly rough, and the third much better.

I found the course to be relevant and important to the core curriculum but the delivery of this course was so problematic that I feel like that instead of learning the material, all I learnt was how the professor evaluates us and how to do well in his evaluation.

Although the class covered the materials in all introductory Biostats classes, I felt that it was not very well structured. There were almost too many sources of information  lectures, quizzes, class notes, lab reports and as a student, it was hard to understand what was necessary to glean from all of this information. I would have preferred more example-based learning in class with R and less theory. I am shaky at math and so I really feel that examples in class would have been best. For example, Linda Niccolai's class cites theory and example within the same powerpoint and I feel like I've gained so much from her class because it was organized very clearly. With this class, it feels like it is two classes rolled into one with very little to tie them together (R and lecture). I really hope that the next person to teach this class has clearer power points/lecture slides, and spells out the important concepts rather than implying them and deferring to the book. The book is not easy to read nor is it intuitive. I think another text should be consulted in the future.
There are too many materials in the course, some of them are repetitive and not very much helpful.

strengths: The TFs were very helpful.
weaknesses: The combination of R and biostats was hard to handle. More of the class should have been focused on R.

I really liked this class, but it took me awhile to get there! Its the first year its being taught so I think a lot of the initial weaknesses can be attributed to the fact that the course was evolving and changing to become better. Overall, you really do come out with a good understanding of how to use R which is really helpful.

The course felt disorganized overall. There were many working parts which did not fit together cohesively. The readings, lectures, homework, and labs felt unrelated at times. I think that the course should be restructured so that everything builds on itself. We were learning so many things at once and I think in learning details, the broader ideas and applications were lost. For example, learning when to apply a certain analytic method wasn't emphasized. I think that having practice with seeing different data sets and being asked how you should approach analysis would be useful. I think that needing to know mathematical details and specific R codes including arguments, etc. sometimes clouded the overall concepts. I felt as though I was trying to memorize details and equations instead of grasping the larger skills. I still do think that I gained a foundation in biostatistics and R, but the course was not as effective as I had hoped. I think that doing a lot of work outside of class and memorizing formulas, assumptions of tests, and specific R code was critical for success in the class because these details were tested. In my work going forward, I don't think these will be as much of an emphasis and I don't feel as confident in my ability to apply my skills in data analysis.

This course was more tricky than it should have been--preparing for exams felt like I was trying not to be outmaneuvered or confused by wording/phrasing which I think defeats the purpose of a stats class. In my opinion, the goal is to teach students how to conduct statistical analysis and how to understand which tests are appropriate in certain scenarios, but I felt like in this class I was constantly being tricked into giving the wrong answer even if I knew the topic and could apply it in a practical situation.

strength: forced me to read the textbook

cons: I learned the material by myself. The structure of the course wasn't optimized for meeting either goal: learning R and statistics
Lot of reading and learning on own

This course was a disaster. It was poorly organized and poorly executed. We were expected to to learn both R and biostats at the same time and it felt like 2 different classes for a majority of the semester. Neither of which I feel I have properly learned. Way too much was expected of us. 4 exams, 6 quizzes, and weekly labs. Really? Is ALL of that necessary? On top of that we would get "optional" homework in the textbook.  And then every time we were given an exam we were expected to have memorized exact phrases from the book, lecture, and R code. Totally inefficient form of evaluation. In what job will I EVER have to code by hand? That's not the nature of coding and not how you tell if someone understands coding. Also the format of every single exam was different. Mike changed it every time. I never knew how to study for this class. Sometimes he would say ignore the homework (after spending a month telling us to do it) then we had free responses thrown at us then matching questions. The really rich part about the matching was that this was Mike's excuse for putting in less free response. However, in the matching you can select from a word bank, but mike also said the right answer might not even be listed and we need to write it in. How is that any different than a free response? The quizzes were just excessive. The first half of the semester we had pop quizzes every week. I thought this was graduate school. Not some undergrad first year math class. Constant anxiety over these things I had to neglect all my other courses to constantly study for these. Also, why on earth would someone assigned a timed coding assignment? We didn't we have a week to do the code labs so I could actually process and learn on my own instead of just rushing to finish on time by blindly following what my TF said? That's not how to learn code.
I was so looking forward to this class. I really wanted to learn stats. I've never taken a stats course before and needed this knowledge. However, I feel I haven't learned anything and waste time and a lot of money.

I think that I am leaving this course with a solid understanding of statistics. I think that what we learned is very practical and will help me succeed in future public health courses. The weakness was mainly in the beginning part of the semester. I think it was very challenging to be learning the concepts of statistics in tandem with R. I think if we had more time to really understand the stats before beginning to use R, R would not have seemed as daunting.

Honestly, this course was a big struggle. I felt that class lecture time was not used efficiently and that I had to teach myself the majority of the material. Specifically, I felt that sometimes the class got so conceptual that it failed to actually teach me how to use any tangible statistics skills. I was really hoping that I would leave with strong R skills, but the TF for lab did not offer support during lab sections and outside of a few lines of code here and there it was not discussed in class. It was frustrating to feel like I was constantly googling things or teaching myself from the book.

Overall, I think the class was great. If you engaged with the work in a timely manner and were proactive in class and lab you were set up to be more than okay. My only issues came in two places. One, we weren't given the grade tresholds for certian disticntions, which made goal-orienting for the class impssible even after some grades had been given. Secondly, there was a negative echo chamber from other students who were not doing well that I think did a lot to take away from the istructor himself. He made himsefl wildly approachable, could speak to any topic, and is very kind. It was hard to learn when it seemed like he was backed into a corner by students, and I want to emphasize that I feel like this was due to no fault of his own. I am leaving the class feeling extremely well prepared to apply my skills in my professional life, and I think that is a wonderful feeling as well as outcome from the course.

I think that this course suffered from a lack of direction because it and the instructor were so new. I would have the lab assignments be longer-term assignments that we had 1-2 weeks to complete and then lab could be like a discussion where we review homework problems and ask questions about the the takehome R assignment. Tests I would want to have the same format each time. Online quizzes were fine. I liked that homework wasnt graded, maybe in discussion grade it for completeness vs correctness.

This is the third statistics course I've taken at Yale, and it was easily the worst. Concepts were poorly explained in class, if at all. I understand that reading the textbook is an important part of any class -- it is a great tool. However, in this class, the textbook was the only way to learn. Many concepts were barely explained in class, if at all. IF they were explained, they were poorly explained, and they were often simply a copy and paste from the textbook. Class time did not add to my learning experience at all.

Strength: A flexible instructor that wants the best for his students. That is it right there. If every class at Yale could have an instructor like Mike, I'd be beyond happy. He made the course. He made it approachable he made it doable and he made it fun. He took S&DS 103 and made it even better. This was my second stats course at Yale (after 103) and I am confident when I say I learned far more in this class than the other. Learning R was a HUGE benefit and I feel like I now have the basic skills in a language that I can build upon should I choose to. 

Weakness: It found its groove at the end. Any perceived weaknesses early on were adjusted and mitigated by course end.

I very much enjoyed this course. The workload was fair, labs felt relevant to the lecture material (and vice-versa), and quizzes and exams were well-spaced. R was well integrated into the course and was taught as a tool not just for data analysis, but as a way to improve understanding of biostatistics. I've come away from the course feeling literate in biostats and prepared to use R in the "real world."

A lot of material was covered and I feel as if I have gained competency in both biostats and R. R came a little harder as we did not have as much formal instruction in it. I would recommend a separate R lecture or a discussion section just for R. Lab was overwhelming as I felt as if I had to learn on the fly and just get through the lab without much prior knowledge of the things lab was asking of us.

The TA's need to be vetted before being assigned to teach. 

Further, there should be some R prep materials given in the summer to incoming students. This would be very helpful. 

Overall assessment is that this is a good course, but it needs some renovations in regards to the quality of the TAs and initiatives on how to make R more accessible to the incoming students.

It's difficult to combine R statistics with theoretical statistics so it might be better to offer them as separate classes. Adding a required discussion or having longer labs might be more useful than a long class period.

Lots of R learning materials are provided which are very helpful, especially for new learners.
One suggestion is I think the exam could include R coding on computer. Actually, it's meaningless to exam the ability of writing R code by hand. In practice, when we make mistakes we can be alerted by the computer. Maybe take home exam is a proper way to check our R coding ability on computer.
Course was disorganized. Mistakes in homework assignments and exams made learning more difficult.

It is difficult to critique a course that is under new instruction because the material was clearly newly developed as the course progressed. I think given the overhaul of the course, it was a fairly strong course. However, it was weak in the presentation of material, which lacked order and direction at the beginning of the semester. While this did get better of the course, I think it is imperative that the instructors consider adding a second lecture to teach R. I do not think it is effective to teach statistics and R in the same course lecture. A student needs to fully understand the statistical methods being applied by the R script and many students, I believe, were so focused on learning R that the statistical knowledge became secondary. Additionally, the course relied very heavily on the book, which is fine, however it would have been helpful for the instructor to synchronize the book with the lecture more effectively.

Really enjoyed the lectures, especially at the beginning when it was more of a conversational setup. Appreciated the posted lecture notes and lab primers. I felt the quizzes and exams were fair and fairly graded. The only weakness of the course was the lab. I felt as though the actual lab assignments were very long, so the class relied on the TA to help guide us and we were not truly understanding why we were using the codes we were using for each step of the lab. For future, I would recommend an R primer be sent out either over the summer or during orientation so students who have never worked with R before have some exposure and familiarity before the first lab. Second, I would recommend that the actual lab assignments be made shorter so the class can submit the assignment early and then the TA can take 20-30 minutes explaining why particular codes were used for certain steps, so as to facilitate actual learning of R.

Strengths: the content is very important and useful. Labs were fun and helpful to build coding skills in R. I enjoyed doing lab exercises and I actually felt like I got to apply my skills. Office hours were helpful, and I appreciate the Prof. Wininger was very willing to meet with students to check in with them or answer any concerns or questions they had about the material. Practice quizzes, study guides, and lab primers were helpful for students to study. Prof. Wininger is incredibly responsive and receptive to feedback. He changed his pedagogy throughout the semester to meet students where they were at. He genuinely cared about his students and wanted them to do well. 

Weaknesses: 1) This class lacked a lot of consistency in the beginning. The homework, lecture notes, labs, quizzes and exams were all in different platforms. Each and every single one of these had a different format, so students had to adjust their brains to each and every single of these formats (then, on the exams we were asked to code by hand, but throughout the semester we coded on our computer! These two formats were different). So, studying exams was difficult and overwhelming because the professor would test us on very, very minute details in the book (like a single line) or a code from some lab. BUT, all that said, exams 3 and 4 were much better in terms of directions to study as Prof. Wininger prepared for us the study guides, so we were able to narrow down the amount of material to focus on. But I wish there was more consistency - every time there was a change in the structure or pedagogy, people didnt know what else to expect. 2) I find professor Winingers lecturing style hard to follow if he wrote things on the iPad, and frankly, the classrooms setup wasnt super conducive. It was hard to stare at a small screen when the lecture notes were in font size 10-12. But things were much better when prof. Wininger explained things on the board using his marker! He did that during office hours and review sessions and it was massive improvement. 3) Although the class did better overall toward the end of the semester and prof. Wininger genuinely wanted us to do well, I felt that we were all caught up in the how-to-beat-the-test mentality rather than actually going to class to enjoy learning. In lectures, instead of going over the concepts from point A to point B, prof. Wininger would highlight stuff and tell us to know them because they will be tested on. I dont think that is helpful for us to learn because if we dont understand the material, it doesnt matter if well do well or not. It felt like we were instructed on how to beat the test than to understand the concepts thoroughly. 4) I didnt like how R skills were tested. I think it is quite ridiculous to ask students to code by hand on the exam, frankly because thats not how were going to do that in the real world. I dont think any employer would ask us to code by hand before hiring us. And a lot of the codes can be looked online. I think a final data analysis project would be a better way to test us on our R skills because wed get to actually code on our computers - which is what we actually do in the real world - while applying a lot of the concepts we learn in lectures. 5) I did not like how early the class was. It is hard for me to math that early in the morning

Strengths: teaches you both statistics and ability to use R
The organization of how R was taught could be more succinct. The course just dove in to R without really going over the basics of what is what in the software itself.

Strengths: It tries to teach a free analytical computer program.
Weaknesses: The textbook is difficult to read if you don't have a strong math background, and the class in general feels like it's catered to biostats or stats students, which is unfortunate because very few of them take that class. It's also hard to evaluate the class because things kept changing all of the time, sometimes we would have a detailed lecture, sometimes it would just be chatting, sometimes the quizzes would test knowledge that was from the textbook and sometimes it would test us on things from the homework. This is especially upsetting because the homework was "optional"--direct statement from the Professor, but a vast majority of his lectures, tests, and quiz questions were based on the homework. We also rarely went over the homework, which made it even more difficult to comprehend. The course was also required us to complete an assignment in about an hour and a half, which was extremely difficult when your TF never explained what to do in the first place. We also only had exams, which isn't really conducive to testing us on our R capabilities.

My overall assessment of the class is pretty poor. There were many weaknesses in combining biostatistics with R. Could be improved by offering a module over the summer and an extra hour of "R discussion" similar to how we have a discussion for Epidemiology.

I think this course was one of the worst experiences I have had in my academic courses. I do not believe it to be a representation of Mike's work with the class, but merely the setup and the lack of preparation for what this class really looks like. There should be a reevaluation of the textbook for this course, because it is not user-friendly, and doesn't address the use of R and the material successfully. There should really be powerpoint style slides, with the amount of theory and wordy rhetoric used throughout the chapters. As for the lab and the class improved after a lot of backlashes, communication with administration, etc. There were multiple situations where I referred to other university's biostats ppt slides, to teach myself the material, because we had no such resoures. It was too late for a lot of these students, including myself. The sole strength of the course was Mike's ability to respond to student's on a beyond timely fashion. But with that said, unless this course is changed completely and students are provided support prior to even walking into the class, I would not recommend this class to anyone, even though it is a core class.

Weakness: Class time was used really poorly; grading was an absolute rollercoaster; homework was orders of magnitude more difficult than the exams, so actually doing it all was not time-efficient (I ended up just reading the answer keys to study).

Strengths: I actually thought the labs were done pretty well. I liked the quizzes, since they forced me to keep up with the material, but maybe having them more consistently (i.e. weekly) would be better.

Strengths:
-Expectations for labs, quizzes, and exams were all extremely clear after adjustments were made mid-way through the semester. I was never taken by surprise by the structure of assignments or tests, which was a huge relief (especially compared to some other courses I took this semester). It made it a lot easier to study, and, more importantly, allowed me to understand how much time I needed to dedicate each week to ensure that I was fully grasping the material covered.
-Mike was incredibly accessible. He went above and beyond to make sure students felt comfortable and his positive and encouraging messaging made a big difference for an otherwise challenging course.
-Lab primers were enormously helpful.
-Take home quizzes (as opposed to in class pop quizzes) were a much better way to test understanding of the material. If in-class quizzes are considered next semester, I think it would make more sense to notify students in advance so they could employ ample time to prepare.

Weaknesses:
-Design and logistical structure of the course. This was addressed in a breakout session for constructive criticism in the course about halfway through the semester, but more specifically:
1) There was a huge discrepancy between "levels" of my various classmates. If we all took a placement test prior to the start of the course, we could be grouped according to our previous exposure to the material (maybe by lab sections?). Ultimately this course would be better broken into sections based on previous stats/biostats experience, or as a individual statistics courses relevant to departments or professions corresponding to those departments. I'm not sure if this would go against accreditation standards, but it would be a more practical approach. 
2) Folded into this, the idea that we should be teaching one another in labs -- as opposed to the TFs -- was a huge problem. I was often distracted by other students who were struggling in labs if I felt like I understood the material and they needed help, or vice versa.
3) Huge discrepancy between TFs and teaching styles. This was exacerbated by labs where (as mentioned above) students often found themselves teaching one another instead of the TFs doing so.
3) No caps on lab sections, meaning some labs had upwards of 40 students, and others had half that. I was in a larger lab which made it nearly impossible for my TF to dedicate adequate attention to ensure that we were all learning and understanding the material (though she did her best!).
4) Labs would have been better with additional time to understand and submit the material. If labs were used strictly to teach content and then students were allowed an additional 24 hours to complete the lab assignment, I know it would have made a huge difference for me. Sitting in a crowded lab setting with other stressed out students was not conducive to productivity. 
5) Volume of content was generally too high. Combining theory and R was too much at once, especially for those of us lacking a background in statistics.

For the class content, a few additional things:
-Hand coding R on exams -- I didn't find this particularly practical as it's not how you would use R in the real world. 
-Little connection between theory learned in class and practical application in labs. I often felt as though every lab was like starting from scratch as opposed to building on material we learned in class or from previous lab sections.

Suggestions:
1) Provide a placement exam for incoming students next year.
2) Split the course into two sections: one half of the semester an intensive focus on theory, the other on statistical software (or this could even be split into two semesters, though I suppose it would restrict electives for some departments).
3) Uniform training of TFs.
4) Caps on lab/section sizes.

The course was great but there was to much material for students to go through. I understood it was from Mike's desire to provide us with as much as possible, but it became burdensome and not too conducive to learning the material. The textbook was excellent and served as a central resource when things got out of hand.

I learned a lot. It was hard to learn R from scratch at the beginning which was discouraging but the lab primers later on in the semester helped a lot. It was difficult to have to translate R code for the test because that isn't how you figure out if the code is correct. Coding is interactive but the tests weren't. I thought the answer choices on tests were very difficult-a, b, a or b, and and b etc. 
Strengths-I feel like I learned a lot and it was useful. I can see the value in understanding conceptually a lot of what we learned in reading scientific papers etc.

professor wininger really made an effort to listen to the concerns of the class and he addressed them accordingly. his passion for statistics is contagious and made the class even more enjoyable. he made the lectures understandable and was very open-minded.

Having the outline of the lecture for the day was beneficial to takes notes during class. The tests and quizzes mainly follow the book which can be helpful because you mainly know what to look for but It can also take a few exams to figure how to study for the exam based on the types of questions asked. The beginning of the course was extremely confusing attempting to learn both statistics and R programming. For individuals completely new with R it would be beneficial at least for the first few lab periods to have to be taught R. The TF should lead a group discussion of how to solve the problem allowing students to answer it pieces together.
Material tested did not align with material taught which made it difficult to study for tests. Material taught in class was significantly easier than what was tested on.

I think the course content was reasonable. It was a typical intro stats course, plus learning a language. I think it often pandered too heavily to people who did not study well, and other times left prepared people behind. The mix of R and basic stats was a little clunky.

Strengths - good course content in regard to concepts covered, learning R is very practical and a good skill to have (lab sections facilitated all of this - taught by TFs)

Weaknesses - scattered course materials/too many course materials that were not concise, poor meshing of conceptual with R work, quiz questions often phrased in confusing ways that did not accurately test understanding
I enjoyed learning R.
The course basically taught me how to teach myself concepts.

Strengths: learning r

Weaknesses: class size. Mixed levels of experience meant we went very slow at times
This course presenting challenging concepts and topics and was structured in the best it could in order to try and teach the concepts it needed to.

Good. We got to learn basic data science. However, it is mostly a conceptual level course, if students are looking for a course which can improve their problem solving skills, it may not be what they are looking for.

I think this class SIGNIFICANTlY improved after the course recalibration after the 2nd exam. I think shifting the focus away from calculations and toward concepts and applications was very useful and made a lot more sense for this class. I also appreciated the addition of lab primers, class notes, and study guides to help students prepare before getting into classroom. I also think the grading structure was very generous and provided many opportunities for students to succeed, despite the course itself being challenging.

That said, this class was unnecessarily stressful in a lot of ways and could be improved for next year. First, providing students with an R "crash course" either before or during orientation would be incredible. I (and most of the class) entered the lab room on the first day with absolutely no coding background being told to "figure it out." For someone who has never interacted with a coding platform before, this sink or swim mentality was unhelpful and did not facilitate learning in any way. I think providing a way to get comfortable with the software before working with it on a timed, graded assignment would be extremely helpful for students. Second, I would reduce the reliance on multiple choice questions that have "both a and b" and "neither a nor b" as possible answers. I think these kinds of exam questions confuse students more than tests their knowledge about certain concepts and leads to more frustration. Third, if possible (and I think this would be consistent with the course recalibration), I think it would be helpful for the instructor to provide more examples of how biostatistics is used in every discipline of public health rather than just Epi. Specifically, many health policy and health care management students are left wondering what the application of this material would be to their work, apart from understand basic interpretable concepts. Fourth (and I realize this was difficult to do because this was the first time the course was taught), it would be helpful to outline the expectations of the students at the very beginning of the course, specifically, what score is needed to pass. I think there was a lot of anxiety about this before Mike announced it 2/3 through the way through the semester. Fifth, TFs should be hired on their ability to teach labs as well as their knowledge of statistics. Some labs had a "sink or swim"/ "teach yourselves and I'm here for questions" mentality, and other labs provided more hands-on support. Unfortunately, students could not choose labs based on their learning style; we chose only based on compatibility of the lab section with our schedules. So, not everyone ended up in a lab that fit their learning style. I think having some uniformity about how labs are conducted would be helpful. Additionally, holding the lab sections in rooms that accommodate both the type of work (i.e. make sure there are enough tables), and the number of students would be helpful. Finally, I think the reliance on the book makes the class unnecessarily difficult. The book is very informative, but not always easy to understand for someone without an background in statistics. If the class is to follow the book exactly, I think the instructor should focus the class time on outlining expectations for understanding book material and explaining those concepts in terms other than what is stated exactly in the book to make sure students understand. Mike definitely did more of this as the semester went on, but generally, if the course is going to be book-heavy, the class time needs to focus more on explaining the book in a reasonable way. 

An alternative solution (though I'm not sure how feasible this is): Biostats is a very useful course, but applied very differently across disciplines. It may be beneficial to teach different courses specific to each discipline rather than having all 200 first years in the same room. This specific application might make the course more useful for students.

Test questions were far too specific.  The test questions should reflect more real world Biostatistics problems.
There should've been lecture slides.  The lecture notes were too difficult to follow.
Split the semester in half and do Biostatistics theory learning for half and R for the other.  And give us more projects in R.
Give us an R textbook. 

Overall, course was confusing to follow.

This course went over a lot of relevant content and taught me skills that will be useful throughout my public health career. I think an R or stats bootcamp in the summer would have been helpful for those of us coming in with very little stats experience.  It would also have been nice to have the R learning be more take home project-based. Doing the R projects during lab was very stressful for people with little experience.

-need standardized lab sections with TFs following the same teaching practices
-need step by step instructions with R studio

I believe it is well-documented that the course had a rough start, but I left the course with positive feelings. I feel I developed skills in Biostatistics that will be helpful to me in public health.

This was single worst educational experience of my life. The course design was not conducive to learning. Rather, pure memorization was expected (like writing code by hand). I feel like I did not gain practical skills for using biostatistics. From the tests that contained erroneous material to the inconsistencies in what is expected to be known, this course was definitely the worst part of my semester.

The major weakness of the class was its design, which destined our instructor to be stretched too thin. The class design was to teach ALL levels of statistics knowledge and also pile on R, which felt excessive. At the beginning of the semester we took a skills assessment for the sake of Mike, but those assessments felt like they were never looked at again besides as a benchmark for progress. I feel those assessments should be used for placement into different stats courses to allow for the most amount of growth for each student.

Strength: the professor is really trying to help students to learn 
Weaknesses: the structure of this class is not well established. For example, evaluating students based on a weekly homework problem set probably will be more efficient than a weekly quiz.
This was a very interesting and rewarding course. It was also extremely difficult. I loved it though.

The course seemed disjointed. R programming seemed to be emphasized over actual statistics most of the time. It seemed like two separate courses. The instructor tried to remedy this in the second half off the course.
Perhaps have a discussion section similar to Foundations of EPI on fridays, and have 2 days worth of lab alternating with the MW course schedule.

Strengths: professor was very dedicated and passionate about the course, interesting course material, exposure to both r and biostats was interesting. 
Weaknesses: lab was extremely variant in terms of quality and teaching based on teaching fellow, and learning both r and biostats at the same time was very overwhelming which was compounded by the fact that we were never really taught r (not in lab nor in lecture). Structure of the course was quite unorganized in the beginning of the course, but was improved by the professor in the latter half of the course (this improvement was very helpful- wish it could have been done earlier). Mistakes were often made in posted homeworks and grades (when I told the professor my grade was wrong he was quick to fix it, but of course it would be ideal if the mistake hadnt been made in the first place).

This class was extremely frustrating for many, including those that were very interested in the material. After each exam, the professor would change his teaching style, which is great in the sense of him being responsive to class feedback but extremely difficult for the students that were all attempting to navigate how to acclimate to him. I have always loved Statistics and was very excited to learn how to navigate a new language but I felt that most of the class I was attempting to learn how Dr. Wininger was going to test us on the material rather than actually learning the material that was presented. Additionally, it did not feel that the amount of work put into the class was rewarded in actual ability to answer questions that he wanted us to. In the end, much of the class had such a low moral concerning the course that we lost hope in being able to see the reward for our efforts.

This was a frustrating course for me because I came into it with high expectations and very excited to lay a biostatistics foundation and learn R. I think the course in general was taught from a statistics perspective, and I think we could have benefitted from a more applied class with more connections to public health research and practice.

It got much better towards the very end of the course.

I wish we were taught the mechanics of the stats in class instead of spending more time on the more basic aspect of a concept. For example, instead of simply talking about how to run an anova, explaining more why you do it, why you type certain things in the code, and how it may be useful in a real-life application. 

I felt that the quizzes and exams earlier on were testing on very nitpicky details of the stats but not necessarily if we conceptually understand it and know some of the important aspects of it. There were questions on quizzes and exam that I felt were very minute and doesn't matter in the long run. 

I wish there was an R primer or something before the course started or more instruction as we eventually got in the course for the lab. R for most of us is a new language and trying to understand how to program on top of that was a steep learning curve. Along with the primers, it would be nice to know why we're doing certain things instead of being told that's how you run a certain line of code.

Strength: use of R software, quizzes fairly straight forward 
Weakness: needs to be smaller, fairly weak/incompetent instructor and TA, unfairly administered exams,
The course could have been much better with a supportive instructor and a more helpful teaching staff. The material was all very useful but it required a lot of independent learning.

Lab is a critical component of the course, and I enjoyed learning R but would have enjoyed it more if the lab did not have a time limit to be due. We should have the whole week to work on it if the intent is truly to learn the material.
great! really learnt about the usage of R and stats.

The workload for this class was outlandish, even for the average public health student who had background experience in the material, and in data analysis. I can't imagine how bad it would be for someone just entering the field. For comparison, I took a combined graduate level/ undergraduate level bio statistics course while I was an undergraduate (with grad students and undergrad students doing exactly the same work and material, minus the undergrads having a final exam and the grad students having a final project), and had to completely teach myself SAS for that previous course because it was assumed everyone already knew how to use it. I ended that previous class with a great grade, after putting in alot of work and teaching myself SAS. This current Yale class was MUCH more work, and my grades on exams were much worse in that class, despite presenting similar base knowledge. I do not feel comfortable using R at all ending this class. In fact, I think I would know how to use R better than I do now if I took all of the time I spent in this class and applied it toward learning R by myself.

The course was designed to assess statistics and R skills but I dont feel that I learned significant R skills to apply outside of class. Also, I dont think we were given enough material to learn R outside of class. In regards to the statistics content taught in the class, it was more conceptual than any math class Ive ever taken and required more reading than I anticipated. If the goal of the class was to teach statistics concepts, then I think the course achieved that. But in terms of applying the concepts to math problems, there wasnt a lot of that.

Strength: the textbook provided a good introduction
Weakness: the course was a little disorganized, concept materials should be taught clearer, and maybe learning SAS would be more helpful than R
Imporvements: doing more problems in class

I really liked the grading scale for this course. The fact that quizzes and labs were 40% of our grade and each exam was worth 15% of our grade took the pressure off of exams. I really liked how Professor Wininger dropped three of our lowest lab grades and two of our lowest quiz grades. It is a difficult and stressful subject, but the grading scale was fair, and it decreased the amount of stress associated with the class. Moreover, I liked the textbook for this class. Its explanation of the statistical concepts were really helpful. I also liked how Professor Wininger provided us with a detailed study guide about what exactly is going to be on the exams. In addition, I liked the multiple choice portion of the exams, but I didn't like writing out code by hand. Another improvement I would suggest is going over the R material in more depth during the lectures. Many of us have never coded in R, so we were going into the labs with little to no foundation in coding, which made keeping up with the work difficult.

Strengths are the course really emphasize on R, and combine the practice with learnings. This is really great, and I feel I am not that afraid of R anymore.
Weakness is, the examples of the book are great, but why we use some other examples that are more confusing in class?

This remains controversial - I thought that the textbook provided was very useful, and easy to comprehend. Many of my colleagues however, thought that the textbook was dense and did not complement the course material. I would say that reading the textbook chapter before classes definitely helped understand the more conceptual course material. However, without reading the textbook, and relying solely on lecture slides, was a little confusing.

The course tried to balance between our comprehension of R software, conceptual biostatistics knowledge, and the application through labs. I thought this was good, but perhaps the course structure could be better.

Weakness: The lab section was often confusing and rushed. Since we were only given 1.5 hours to solve a short-to-long assignment set, during the first weeks, when most of the class had 0 R knowledge, we had to rely on the TFs to guide us through the session. In later weeks of the semester, if we were stuck on bugged code or forgot some concepts, we would run out of time to finish the assignment.
I would suggest to reformat the Lab section into take-home assignments, so that students can have time to look at Stackoverflow, course content, etc. so that everyone can do it at their own pace. I think that this method would make the material stay longer in the students' brain too.

This class wasnt my favorite statistics class I have taken. I felt as the material was all over the place especially when including r in the course outline. There really should have been separate class for r and this statistics class should have stuck to the foundations of statistics. I believe the lab should have furthered the material taught in class instead of solely focusing on r.

Strengths: Adaptive teaching style, Covered important material
Weakness: Incorporating R coding into exams. I felt our familiarity with R could have been better assessed in a lab/test environment.

Overall, I am incredibly disappointed in this course. I had (have?) no background in bio/statistics and was excited to learn and understand how to apply statistics to the work I have done, am doing, and will do. I got nothing but struggle and strife from this course. The material was dense and not presented well at all. Lectures were very scattered/aimless, homework was assigned without review or guidance, there was no connection between statistics and the R coding and programming.

The lectures and lab sections have nothing to do with each other - one did not help or even connect to the material in another (unlike my other classes). Using R in lab was stressful and disjointed. I wish there had been some sort of primer or review in the summer to have better prepared me. 

We took a sort of diagnostic test at the beginning of the semester, presumably to gauge our skill level - but i dont know that anything came from that. It would have been nice to have sections for beginner/intertermediate/advanced - based on student experience and skill level. 

After talking to some of the AP students who took biostatistics in the summer, they did not have the same complaints /sentiment - wondering why admin/the department didn't just use the same Professor/design of that class instead of testing this out on us. I know i'm not alone in feeling this way. 

after a semester of hard work, I don't understand biostatistics or statistics any better/at all.
it's interesting material but the lectures were not conducive to learning - relied heavily on the book

This was the most frustrating course I have ever taken. I felt like there was no way to learn the material because the instructor was ineffective, and with other classes, seminars, and a job it is impossible to spend hours and hours each week teaching yourself the material. First of all, the class was much too big to be able to effectively teach this subject. Some subjects are better suited to a lecture style and others are not suited to it at all. During the lecture, it was difficult to hear everything the professor said because the room was so long. The lecture notes were not helpful because they did not explain the material differently than the book had. Criticism about teaching style was met with defensiveness. People without math/science backgrounds were made to feel inadequate. We were promised the first day of class that we did not need to have any experience with R, but it was never taught well. In labs we were left to struggle through the material with minimal guidance. In other lab sections the TFs taught R code and guided students through the labs. Other TFs even provided review sessions for their sections! The instructor said that TFs could decide their own teaching style but clearly some students had an enormous advantage because they had helpful TFs. The room where our lab was held did not have adequate table space and when we brought this to the instructor's attention, he told us that he would see if we could switch rooms. Nothing happened and I though that there were no other available rooms. Then one day towards the end of the semester our TF didn't show up to lab so the instructor came. He claimed to be surprised by how bad our room was and that he had no idea of the issue. His office hours were held at a time when many students had lab for the class.

The strength of this course was that it was a good overview of statistics. However, I feel as if it should have had more of an R focus or integration. It would be useful if one day of the week was used to review material from the book and explain concepts and the second day of the week was to go through a homework-like problem together/using R. I think that it would be a great class if it better integrated R into the statistical theory. As well, it would be nice to use math more rather than simply theory. In the end, the tests were good about setting up equations and applying the math. Overall, the greatest strength of the class was the number of resources that were available to the students and the fair testing on concepts. All information on tests stemmed from the lectures and homeworks.

This course was a good opportunity for R learning starters. With labs focusing on practicing data cleaning and data analysis, I was able to get a primary understanding of R coding. However, this course spent a lot of time drawing graph and some too basic concept like mean and median. The time arrangement could be better.

By July and the timing of theoretical text book learning and practical R learning so that the learning curve for both components are equal and complementary. Otherwise, can be overwhelming, especially to beginners. 

Course difficulty and demand is comparable 
to a non-math major pre-med math undergrad course at Dartmouth (my alma mater). 

Therefore, this biostat course is  very reasonable for an Ivy League graduate program in public health.

Very good course but the workload was equivalent to that of at least 2 courses and not just one. There were too many assignments/activities required for completion in order to truly do well: 1) Reading of assigned material in the textbook, 2) Homework assignments, 3) Lab primers, 4) Labs in addition to quizzes and exams. It was overwhelming and I eventually gave up on trying to master the material. 

Lab sessions were very stressful. The graded assignments were too long given the amount of time allotted for the session. It felt like a stressful race to figure out the material together with my classmates and not a truly relaxed and positive learning environment.

This course has many ups and downs. I urge everyone to review the lecture notes from the first six weeks of class so it can be understood how little we were taught versus how we were expected to perform. I self taught myself everything for the first exam over the course of a week reverse engineering the homeworks because we were simply not taught anything that we were tested on outside of what was in the book. His notes were unorganized stream of consciousness and the r code we were given was just that- given, not explained or defined so we were scrambling to put together correct chains of code in lab to complete on time all while not really knowing what we were typing or the meaningfulness of our analysis, so we had not way to actually learn anything and take it forward. I managed to pull out an acceptable grade, but as the material got harder it became harder to self teach and I, like a majority of the class, faltered on the second exam and still do not understand why there was not a curve to make up for that speedbump in all of our grades, since a universal dip indicates a flaw in the professor and not the student. This is not to say I didn't have improving of my own to do, but I am saying that I was alone on that process and the professor did not adjust his teaching style once he was forced to. It was a helpful change. The structured notes allowed me to learn and build on existing knowledge and I did excellent on the third exam. However, this increase in detail of his lectures led the professor to choose increasingly obscure concepts to test us on.  He provided where we could find each and every answer, however sometimes we were supposed to have memorized a throwaway concept that he had written in the footnotes at the bottom of the page. Fair game is fair game, but I think the flaw here is that we were not tested on execution or understanding but on seemingly random parameters and rules to the math that are not important in true practice.
Course was disjointed; lectures, homework, labs, and exams did not feel connected in terms of relevant material.

This course was a struggle, to say the least. One strength is that the course introduces students to R and stats methods. However, having finished the course, I still do not feel fully confident in my ability to use R because codes were only briefly mentioned in class and tested out in labs. A module explaining how to use R would have been helpful, as I did not know how to even open a script or input code prior to my first lab. Additionally, labs were incredibly stressful given their time constraint, lack of structure, and general unfamiliarity with using R. There is a lot of room for improvement with this class going forward.

I really enjoying the programming aspect of this course, but I wish the labs were available for a longer time period, or that we had a semester-long project. I felt that I was able to execute everything that was needed in labs, but hardly ever understood what we were doing until the very end of the lab because it was so fast-paced and frantic. I was in a section that was very full, and it was complete chaos. The class itself was also good and I learned a lot, although I thought it was my worst subject.

Strengths are that he is very adaptable and tried to take feedback and use it to improve. Weaknesses are that he wouldn't explicitly say what was important for us to know. Also, the course seemed a bit disorganized. Things would be changed all the time in our homework or on a test.

Less esoteric vocabulary on syllabus/introduction of course concepts, at least initially when we are still trying to learn the jargon.
Either make lecture mandatory or not--don't punish students by not allowing them to see quiz passwords if they're videocasting the lecture, etc. If lecture is mandatory, just say so.
Clearer lecture structure and exams that are reflective of lecture (rather than the book, I can read the book at home)

Very kind and understanding; more than willing to help at literally any hour of the day, any day of the week. Changing the structure of the class notes would be helpful because they are not in-depth enough with the textbook. It feels like they touch on some sparse key points but not all of the key points so it is hard to know what to review when looking at them at the end.
Good

Professor Wininger definitely cares about his students and has good intentions, however he wasted a lot of class time as an instructor. I wish that he would have taught actual statistics instead of going over his lecture notes and referring to page numbers during the class. He also spent way too much time talking about exams. One day I think we actually spent 30 minutes looking over two plots of test scores in comparison time we opened the psets all to make the point that our poorer test scores were our own fault. Honestly, if we did poorly on the test, then the teacher is probably someone at fault not just us. Also it's okay if you're students are mad at you; not everyone is going to like you. I didn't want to be babied when I got a bad test score, I can handle myself.

Really like the first version of him. When he explained everything and run the class in a more flexible way, rather than strictly following notes.
He is really willing to hear to students, and that is extremely positive.
He answer all questions kindly and with patience.
He provided with extra lecture notes, primer for labs, and everything students asked to try to help us.
He really knows a lot about R and stat.
he was so, so helpful, but i think there needs to be more focus on whether we should know R or know stats.

I was very impressed by the quality of Professor Wininger's teaching. He was engaging, knowledgeable, and went above and beyond what was required of him to ensure that the students in his class understand the material and see the real-world application of the course content. I came into this course with a considerable amount of trepidation about the material but was able to do well in the course because of the resources provided by Professor Wininger.
Dr. Wininger was very engaging and knowledgable. While his teaching style was good, the organization of the class was poor.
Good, but catered too much to students. Needed to just teach and we can learn and catch up.

Mike made an intimidating class seem very accessible and, in some cases, fun. Being tasked to teach a course like biostatistics to a groups of people with WIDELY variable skill/familiarity with statistics and math in general is a big ask, and I think that he did a really amazing job with the resources he had and the length of the course. He adjusted his expectations/direction of the class according to student feedback and what he interpreted to be the  the purpose of the class. That is just one example of Mike being flexible, accommodating, and dedicated to the success of the students and this pilot course. Although I cannot speak to previous iterations of the course, I think that Mike did an amazing job at fielding all the questions/challenges/anxieties students had around the class. 

All of this is NOT to say that he was a pushover or did not make the class challenging. I learned a lot through this course and the pace was, at times, very challenging. However, I think that it would be hard to be critical of Mike's contributions as a professor. His output of content for the course was much more than any other professor in the core curriculum between homework, answer keys, practice problems/quizzes, lecture notes, the coding diary, study guides, etc. He also doubled his office hours in the later portion of the course. Ultimately, I very much enjoyed the course and Mike as a professor/person.

I like Mike, but again I wish the class would have been smaller because I think he taught really well in the small group reviews and when he led my lab section once. He was always available for help and gave us alot of opportunities to practice problems with homework. I really appreciate how he took our feedback into consideration toward the beginning of the semester.
He is very nice and funny, and very considerate to everyone (it's a big class), but sometimes too many in-class stories...

Mike was supportive of students doing well and was prompt when replying back to emails.  However, in the beginning of the semester he offered no real concrete help or assistance in changing his teaching styles when the majority of the class was evidently struggling with how he taught.  It took several stressful months for him to finally recognize that how he was teaching was not conducive to a positive learning environment.  Only then did he take real action to help and support us.  However, it was far too late into the semester and should have been done the second the majority were showing signs of struggling and were reaching out to him.

I think that Professor Wininger adapted based on feedback and class concerns over the semester and tailored the class very well for MPH students. He was always willing to give feedback and go above and beyond to help students. He always answered my emails in a timely fashion and helped me greatly during his office hours.

Mike is a very nice and committed professor, who tried above and beyond as hard as he had to. I appreciate how much individual attention he gave to students, even in a 200 person class. I think he genuinely tried hard so I dont want my frustrations about this class to be taken out on him personally. 

That being said, this class was a mess, and I think Mikes lack of organization was the biggest downfall. The tests were all confusing, with a bunch mistakes on each one. Lectures were hard to follow ramblings. Why couldnt he just have slides like every other professor that summarize MAIN POINTS, not 11 pages of unreadable r code that you tell us to read later. He could still riff with an organized lecture, but if he had organized slides, I think it would challenge him to focus on the main point. I dont think this is all on him. This is a new course required for all if us- where is the biostats Dept? Why was he left to himself. Why as a new prof, were they not reviewing his teaching materials at all?

The instructor was a very nice person and ultimately cared about his students and their well being. However, making the class and labs more structured would be nice. I think also having the TF's walk through the first few labs would be nice.

Professor Wininger is clearly knowledgeable of the subject matter and was flexible and open to feedback over the course of the semester, however, I do believe the content could be taught in a more understandable, coherent manner.

Mike is a wonderful, dedicated professor. He was great at listening to his students' needs and making real changes based on feedback. I may have put in many hours into this course but I'm sure he put in double. He is also hilarious and great at drawing cartoons. He made it worth it to learn biostats so early in the morning.
Mike is great and super caring. Only issue is that he doesnt tell us the grade cut-offs. But he honestly is one of the most passionate professors i have ever had.

I think he's a good insturctor and he's very energetic and enthusiastic. He's serious on teaching and often encourage us. Although sometimes it's a little hard for me to follow his line of thinking in class, the lecture note is a great material for me to review.
Thank you for trying hard and adapting to the feedbacks. Perhaps can use PPT slides in the future and less writing on the computer.

I think Professor Wininger was in over his head. His knowledge of biostatistics and R influenced his teaching style and he was often too advanced and vague for the knowledge and lack of proficiency of the class. I think his passion for the course material and his love of teaching/his students came through -- I think he would be much better for an advanced or smaller class. I found him to be very very helpful one-on-one during office hours and attended his office hours regularly, which helped me but did require a lot of time outside of class and lab. At the outset of the class, I think he tried to be a fun and likable guy and often got walked all over with students complaining about almost anything. Toward the end of the semester, Professor Winninger seemed to find a rhythm that worked. Posting the R Diary and study guide for exam 3 and 4 was extremely helpful in tying together concepts and understanding important topic connections. 
Overall great guy, tough circumstances.

Professor Wininger was absolutely amazing and the most delightful professor I have encountered at YSPH thus far. He legitimately cares about his students and it shows in his teaching. He was truly invested in seeing the class succeed and really learn the basics of biostatistics. He went above and beyond to provide the class with resources to study with for quizzes and exams. His homework was always posted with the solutions in both R and manually. His passion for statistics shone through in his teaching and made the subject much more enjoyable. He adjusted to the needs and desires of the students whenever requested and even changed his entire teaching style to meet the demands of the majority of the class. I hope he returns to teach this course next year. YSPH needs more professors like him.
I thought he did great and wouldn't say anything should be changed
