The Professor was always scattered and never had clear thoughts, furthermore his quiz and test questions were not a clear reflection of what you know but rather a mind game intended to trick you and not help you learn the material.

i think the instructor was easy to talk to, quick to respond with emails, and overall a nice person.
however, i dont agree with his teaching style at all-
#often a lot of class time would be wasted discussing unnecessary stuff (like the history of p value and mean) and answering a LOT of student questions which could be easily diverted to office hours
#this took away time from important concepts and basic things that we really need to know!!
#he used an iPad to explain things and i really dont think this is the best idea for a stats class- plus he switched up his way of teaching and for some reason decided that its a good idea to project his lecture notes in class (which were 12p font) and use that to explain things- utterly horrible- and not even visible from the back- better if was taught on a white board and we worked on examples together
#quiz questions and exam questions were straight from the book often which is fair, but again, its like whats the point of class? its like he almost wanted us to learn the book & not actually understand stuff
#too much info with not actually useful stuff in it
Like I said before, Mike was sensitive and responsive to student feedback and went above and beyond any expectations to modify the class structure to meet the needs of his students.
Nice person, poor course structure

Mike, compare to all our other professors at YSPH, is by far the smartest and knows his topic the best.  He is the only one who could actually answer all questions posed to him by students.  He was incredibly responsive and very helpful when contacted.  I also appreciated his teaching style of writing as he talked....other professors have perfect slides that they read off of, and its really easy to zone out.  Mike is easier to follow.

Better clarity on what concepts are worthy of testing on, and a solid team of TAs (that Mike didnt have) would help tremendously.  I didnt always understand my other professors either, but there was a TA section I could attend to get that help, where TAs re-taught the material covered that week. Biostats is the only class that didnt have that, because we had to have lab.

Stressful class that I spent a lot of time on.

Mike was awesome. He was funny. Kept you actively listening throughout the lectures. And he was incredibly accommodating. He took mid-semester critiques to heart and was continually changing things based on the feed back of the students in order to make the class better and could not have been better at listening to his students or making time to talk to them and answer questions. He added office hours. He did separate appointments. If you couldn't make it, he even offered to have meetings over Skype. He was great.

I do not enjoy Professor Wininger's teaching style. The lecture notes are hard to follow and do not have any order to them. There is almost no point in showing up to class because teaching myself using the book is a much more effective use of my time.

Mike took the feedback from the mid semester evaluation and incorporated some of the suggestions well. Having a more structured lecture would be helpful, because the lecture notes sometimes contain more concepts than are covered in class.

Michael Wininger is a phenomenal instructor who was emotionally invested in the growth of his students. His start was rocky as this is his inaugural teaching year at Yale but adjusted the course to better fit the needs and expectations of his students. It is this adjustment in the way that he instructed that reflects his ability to be a great instructor going forward here at Yale.
Clearly cares, very nice, but lectures a bit disorganized.

The professor failed to create a positive learning environment. I did not find his lectures to be organized and found it difficult to follow. I also found his examination style to be confusing. It tested our memorization skills rather than our knowledge. Overall, for an entry level course, the professor had no idea on how to judge our capability as a group and had too many expectations. Had unrealistic goals from us and was very stubborn to change or receive feedback. I think he might be better suited for an advanced course instead of an entry level course.

It was a joy taking Professor Wininger's class. Although the material was challenging, he was readily available to answer questions and always had a positive and encouraging attitude in class. Being that this was the year this course was being taught in this fashion, Professor  Wininger frequently asked for student feedback and modified the course accordingly as the semester progressed. He provided us with plenty of materials to assist our learning--he posted lecture notes before each lecture and edited powerpoint slides after each lecture, he supplied us with lab primers to walk us through our labs and practice quizzes. In response to student feedback, he also began providing us with study guides before our exams. 
Professor Wininger approachable and tried as hard as possible to communicate difficult concepts.

I appreciated him as an instructor because he always made himself quite accessible to the students, however, I am at a loss for the content of the class. I really wish he had been clearer in the organization of the class. The lectures were not as informative as I would have liked (and the book wasn't much help patching together what was an important concept and what was fluff). Overall, I would recommend him as a professor with the understanding that a lot of work/responsibility is placed on the student to learn. This can sometimes feel overwhelming.

Prof Wininger has been considerate to the students throughout the class, he sent me emails when I was not doing quite well at the beginning of the course. However, I have to say that the class was not very much helpful for me to understand the knowledge. I have to learn most of the knowledge of the class by myself.
He needs to focus more on R than he did. Majority of R was taught by the TFs and not the instructor.

Prof Wininger was fantastic. He really cares about his students and was so committed to the class in a way that made me want to do better and learn more. He was really available when students needed help, willing to hear feedback and critique, and super responsive to what the students wanted.

Professor Wininger was understanding of students' needs and concerns. I think that in responding to feedback, however, the course actually became less effective because priorities were shifting, there were delays in course materials being uploaded, and we lost instruction time discussing administrative issues in the beginning of class. I think that Professor Wininger cares about students and is very knowledgable, but the course was not as organized as it should have been.

Professor Wininger is a really nice man who cares about his students and is very accessible via email. I think he could be more organized with his lectures and notes (once he began posting notes online I found this much more helpful) and I think he words his test questions in deliberately tricky ways which makes it hard for students to feel confident that they have the skills to conduct statistical analysis. In that sense, I think he may be accidentally undermining the overall goal of teaching students, because the tricky test questions make it feel as though biostats, which should be a straightfoward skills-acquisition course, is something that you cannot prepare for.
Seems to care about students and definitely improved over the course of the semester, but this came a little to late
Does things his own way without regard for how it may affect his students. No practice on how to do calculations by hand. No formal teach of R; sporadic.

Mike seemed to put significant effort forth, took the feedback students gave him, and attempted to make adjustments. He deserves credit for that because not a lot of professors do that. However, I felt that lectures were incredibly unhelpful. Mike's writing on the ipad is not legible a good amount of the time and he speeds through material. He puts written notes on the screen but they are so small that I can't even read them unless im sitting in the very front, which is obviously not feasible for every student. Mike would take every single useless, nitty gritty question from students in the front who never raised their hand and waste an enormous amount of time. Then he would realize he was short on time and speed through material, resulting in me not understanding it. Also, Mike frequently goes on tangents about the history of stats or how we can now code this or that or how we can make publication worthy graphs. He would just talk at us about all the skills we supposedly now have while spending less time actually teaching us these skills. I'm pretty sure he said "you can make publication worthy graphs and figures" at least once per lecture for the last month and half of class. Additionally, he would waste time by saying "you don't need to know this equation" then proceeded to go through every single part of it, then quizzing us on it. What's the point? Waste of time. I think Mike has a hard time making the information accessible to those of us with no stats background, like me. Overall, just really useless lectures. I wanted to skip but I had to keep showing up in case of a surprise extra credit quiz or something. I'm not paying $44,000 to receive an education this poor and wasteful.

Prof Wininger is an outstanding educator. He is so empathic to the student experience and really tries to create a classroom environment that supports learning and curiosity, but yet is still challenging. It is clear that he invests a lot of time into helping his students succeed. Where he struggled was mainly finding the right proxy to assess student's mastery of course material. It took two examinations before I think he really found his stride in creating exam material.

As a person I really enjoyed Mike. He has a great sense of humor and a true genuine desire to see us succeed in statistics. As I stated before, I think some of the problems were less with him as a person and more with the way the class and teaching were structured. I think having more structured and concrete skill teaching would be ideal, with less time vaguely talking about concepts. I had a serious problem with the format of the second exam. He is aware that many students were upset. He came in with only 10 minutes left on the exam to my room, spoke for 5 minutes and changed 3-4 questions. When he finished we had about 6 minutes left. I raised my hand and asked if we would be getting a few extra minutes since he had just taken up time and we would now have to go back to double check questions with changes- even if the correct answer is not changed we still had to go back and take time to check. He responded in a fairly rude tone that I "simply had to take what I know and do it faster." I found this extremely unfair and that was the point that I started really disliking that class. He says that he wants us to succeed yet his practice does not match up with the way that he formats class or exams.

Professor Wininger is one of the best professors I have had in a long time. Although it seems some people had a rocky time in the course, I think it is wrong to say that as a comment on his teaching. He gave us all of the resources we needed to shine (e.g. met with us on weekends to do reviews for tests), was super available, and could always make you smile. He challenged us in a way that would force us to truly learn the material, and that should be appreciated. I think he is a bright young talent, a wonderful human, and nothing but an asset for YSPH.

Professor Wininger was super responsive to student concerns which I greatly appreciated. The course was a mess in the beginning but I feel it greatly improved when Professor Wininger changed his teaching format and focused the lectures. My only comment is that addressing student concerns could take up a lot of classtime, and I would want the professor to be aware of that next time.

Professor Wininger was a really nice and enjoyable person, but his teaching was subpar. He did not add any knowledge not provided by the textbook. He didn't even provide another way of conceptualizing things. He often went on tangents in class, and we rarely covered all of the material we needed to know. He was very invested in the class, and he clearly wanted to improve and be the best teacher possible, but his intentions simply didn't translate into actions.

Amazing. He should be in the hall of fame for instructors. Now I don't really find statistics that interesting. Nor do I think I will go into the field much further. But I would not hesitate in placing EPH505 in the top 5 classes I have taken in 7 semesters at Yale. He is absolutely caring and wants the best for his students. I think he left it all on the field. He poured so much passion into making sure we could succeed. I really felt like the quality of my other courses were not as good compared to EPH505, just because of Mike. Should he ever wish to pick up the teaching torch again (which, Mike, you should definitely take a break after such an intense semester) but, should he-- I think he would be even better. He does something that most professors never do, change. He was willing to make changes to the way he was instructing that allowed for us to learn better. God good, I know this sounds like some love letter but I will miss Mike. He cared. It is as simple as that. It makes me sad other professors don't seem to have that quality about them.

Mike's enthusiasm for biostatistics and genuine care for students' learning (and well-being!) really drove this course. Mike listened to students' concerns and made adjustments to his teaching style when necessary. He provided ample materials to enhance learning (study guides, homework, detailed lecture notes, annotated slides, and bonus points). Every adjustment Mike made to the course structure was clearly out of concern for our learning. Sometimes these adjustments felt as though they were catered to a vocal minority of highly dissatisfied students, and I do wish that Mike sought more student input before switching to the pre-written lecture notes (as these were very small on the screen!), but generally every change was intentional and enhanced the course. 

I sometimes had a hard time knowing what to study for exams since lectures didn't feel super structured (and we had so many sources of information, from the book to homeworks to lecture to labs). However, by the end of the semester Mike was much more clear about how to prepare for his exams. 

Another point of feedback is that it would have been nice to know the Honors/HP/P cutoff before going into the final exam. 

In general, I am truly grateful to have taken this course with Mike. His sense of humor, willingness to make adjustments given student feedback, and teaching of very tangible stats/R skills made this course so much more enjoyable!

Mike was very receptive to feedback and provided as as many resources as possible to help us succeed. I took an introductory stats class twice in undergrad, and this is the first time where I actually felt I learned anything. Mike is so enthusiastic about the subject that he makes it interesting to learn. I went into the class thinking I would hate it, but his instruction in the class made me really enjoy learning biostats. I am so appreciative of him as an instructor. He was so accessible and helpful. My favorite professor by far this semester.
Strengths: Engaging, student-centric, very approachable, funny

In the beginning, there was definitely a disconnect between Professor Wininger's and the student's understanding. However, he's been really receptive and gone above and beyond for his students. He's an amazing person who truly cares for the success of his students.

Prof. Wininger is very patient and always encourage students on classes. One weakness is that the courses are too briefly, especially on Module 3 and Module 4. The course can just cover very few knowledge of each chapter. However, those uncovered knowledge still will be tested. In this way, we need to spend plenty of time outside the classroom.
Accepting of feedback. Attempted to change his teaching style.

Dr. Wininger is a scholar and teacher who cares about his students and tries to provide an optimal learning environment. However, I believe he sometimes teaches above the level of a majority of the students taking the course. But, as I said before, it is a newly developed course and the first time teaching new material to new students is challenging.

Mike is a phenomenal instructor. He presents the material in a way that is easy to understand, is open to taking questions during class so every student understands the material, and goes above and beyond to make himself available for those who need extra help on certain concepts. Really enjoyed taking this course with him!

Mike is very, very responsive and genuinely cares about his students. He made the class enjoyable and filled with positivity despite a lot of the challenges in terms of his teaching and the course structure. I really didnt like his lecturing style on the iPad. He was much better when he wrote things in the board during office hours, and I thought he could incorporate that more in lectures (sadly, the classrooms setup wasnt super conducive for that). He was very helpful during a review session in Winslow when he wrote things on the board So, having a lecture hall with a big black board would be a better setup than having computer screens projecting small size words. I can see that Mike really cared about us and that he was willing to improve his teaching, but I think he focused too much on how to beat the test than actually being more thorough and concrete in his teaching. Like, he would highlight what to know and what not to know for the exams in lectures instead of really teaching us the concepts in a logical manner. Lectures felt very random and disconnected because he wasnt really helping us connect the dots - he focused a lot on what to know and what not to know for the exams. I thought he was very helpful when he went over an example question in class step by step on how to do hypothesis testing. THAT was helpful because we were taught how to get from point A to point B, instead of being informed on whats going to be on the test.

Professor Wininger is very passionate about statistics and really cares about having his students learn the material and succeed. He keeps very clear and open communication about everything going on inside and outside the classroom.

Strength: Cares about the subject. Is funny. Willing to work with student schedules
Weakness: Defensive when taking constructive criticisms from students, makes fun of "poetry majors"--which really just exacerbates the existing tension between hard sciences and humanities which is unnecessary in an industry that must be comprehensive and people-oriented, will email a student who complains that they "only looked at the exam study guide the saturday before the exam" which just shuts down those complaints, has a lot of unguided lectures.

I think Dr. Wininger had the best intentions for the class but I do not believe he was meant to be an instructor for such a large scale class. I think for a lot of the semester he did not understand the pass/fail system of the class, as well as the concept that this was a BASIC biostats class. I think some of the biggest frustrations a lot of us had were that we would never get the step by step process of learning the formulas or theories, but would be tested in a very computerized, theory-based way. It was common that he showed us Step A and then Step C, assuming we knew what happened in Step B. There were multiple situations like this that left so many of us confused. He is a nice man and I do believe him to be so intelligent, however, teaching such a large class, basic information was not his strong suit.

Dr. Wininger did an excellent job of incorporating student feedback throughout the semester. When students found themselves confused during labs, he created a lab primer; when students wanted extra practice questions, he developed practice quizzes. He improved his teaching throughout the semester and was extremely receptive to any feedback, which is an awesome quality for any professor.

Overally, it was clear that Prof. Wininger cared about our performance, had a well-thought-out plan for teaching us, and was always very responsive to feedback. Any issues with him, I believe, are more because it is his first year teaching a course and it is a huge class; they are definitely fixable and he has a great attitude to fix them. One specific improvement I would suggest is better use of class time. He clearly worked to correct poor use of class time by presenting outlines of each lecture and limiting digressions, but neither of these really helped. First, providing an outline of a lecture that doesn't introduce concepts in any order that makes sense is still very confusing. Second, he would focus on the boring or obvious aspects of each thing, making it 15-20 minutes between when anything important was said, and I honestly stopped paying attention. Finally, while the whole iPad/multiple screens thing is cool and flashy, using a stylus on an iPad made the class notes really hard to read and organize on the screen, making everything more confusing. Plus, it was hard to take handwritten notes in class since he was constantly writing and deleting things and they weren't included in the uploaded powerpoint.

As I mentioned in the general course assessment, Mike was incredibly accessible. He went above and beyond to make sure students felt comfortable and his positive and encouraging messaging made a huge difference for a very challenging course.

More specifically, his office hours and setting up additional review sessions outside of office hours were particularly helpful. His teaching in smaller settings was more productive than in the large lecture (which I think is more a reflection of the material itself, not him as an instructor -- I don't think this course should be taught in a lecture setting).

He was absolutely delightful. I think other students gave him really harsh feedback throughout the semester more because of their anxiety about grades, and less about his teaching. I do agree he sometimes gets too advanced for an intro class, but he has always delivered, whether through immediate responses to questions or additional notes. I saw many of his uploads time marked at 3 or 4am, which indicates how much he goes above and beyond for the class. I highly recommend him for an advanced biostatistics course.

I though Mike was fantastic and very adaptable to feedback. Every time I sent him an email he responded promptly and took a great deal of time and pride in getting to know his students. Biostats is inherently challenging, especially on a Monday at 8:30 in the morning, but he made coming to class worthwhile.

professor wininger is extremely kind and was very receptive to critcism throughout the course. he acknowledged his weaknesses like the typos on the homeworks and exams and he worked hard to implement change for this. overall, his strengths greatly outnumber the weaknesses.

Some of the first classes during the semester felt like nothing was learned during class but the material was still expected to be understood. Professor Wininger has a great deal of enthusiasm and wants his students to succeed which is appreciated.
very responsible, but i don't like the way he teaches the second half semester
Worked with students to adjust his teaching style as the semester went on. But was often not completely transparent about grading policies.

Mike cared a lot about his students. I thought he was very prepared. I think he spent too much time letting people argue with him during lecture, which sometimes derailed the topic. Some students acted remarkably entitled, and I think because he cared so much about the class, they tended to take up much of his attention.

At the beginning of the course, Professor Wininger taught step by step from the ground up, told anecdotal stories to help with understanding the concepts, and entertained questions along the way. He was thorough and deliberate and the course, that was new to many students, felt like it was going at a good pace. This lasted until about the first exam, whereafter people complained about different aspects of the course and the professor completely changed his teaching style. Notes consisted of page numbers from the book instead of teaching the concepts outright. The labs were only possible with the help of the TF. Too many materials were posted to canvas that were seen as vital to the understanding of the course. The professor stopped actually teaching in my opinion.
Mike put a lot of time and effort into teaching the class. I thought he did a great job of teaching R in lecture while relating it to book material.

I think Mike is really smart and very nice. He is approachable and great but his teaching style is a little difficult to follow as someone who has not done any math for 3 years. His notes are not very clear after class. But I appreciate his willingness to modify his style.

Enthusiastic and caring instructor. The problems with the course were not due to him being a bad teacher but rather from the broad course structure. He worked individually with me every time I had a problem and was valuable for supporting my mental health. Thanks mike!

Mike was hands down one of the best instructors I have ever had. I have never seen a professor take feedback from students and so quickly incorporate it into his teaching. People struggled with this class and Mike did literally everything in his power to help. To be quite honest, I think the people who were upset with this class were upset from their performance. As a student who struggled a lot on a few of the exams I genuinely believe that Mike was nothing short of fair, and perhaps was too generous, in his preparation and testing of the material.
Good.

Mike clearly cared about making the class a positive experience. I think the course itself has a long way to go to improve for next year, and Mike cares enough and is flexible enough to make those changes. I will say that Mike's teaching style is more compatible with a smaller setting (and is a truly excellent teacher for a smaller audience), so the 200-person format was likely a challenge for both him and the students.

He clearly cares a lot about the course and really wanted to improve it when feedback was given - which was great!  He also clearly spent a lot of time and effort trying to put together helpful materials. 

However, there were too many materials that felt haphazard and confusing (i.e. annotated lecture notes, labs, a textbook, lab primers, homeworks, practice problems, practice quizzes, and quizzes).  I think if the material was more streamlined so that it was clearer what was expected of us, that would've been much better.  He should've just given us lecture slides containing the content we needed to know.

Professor Wininger is so warm and funny. He was a little scattered at the beginning of the semester, but his teaching style with student feedback, which made it much easier to follow what was going on. He is great at responding to student questions (even basic ones) with enthusiasm.

-teacher made many changes mid semester based on student feedback which is great 
-overall, could tell the professor cared about student success

Mike is an excellent instructor. He truly went above and beyond the call of duty to be responsive and to tailor and adjust the course to meet students needs. I highly recommend that he teach this course in the future, especially as the kinks get ironed out of the material and structure itself. I was so impressed with Mikes ability to take constructive feedback and apply it to the course structure in the middle of the semester.

Mike seems to be quite passionate and excited by what he does. He does respond to email quickly and after many requests, began to provide lab primers and other needed resources. Mike can be quite inconsistent with his teaching and does not make it clear what will be tested. He is extremely sensitive to any form of criticism and/or suggestions.

Mike was given the impossible task of teaching to every stats level, which felt unfair. Then he faced the wrath of lots of students who were upset over their grades, and from then on, it seemed like he felt pressured to walk on egg shells. In my opinion, most of the complaints against Mike overshadow genuine critiques that could help him be a better instructor. For example, I think at the beginning of the semester his examples were too high up for us to understand. As the semester progressed, his examples made more and more sense and were more explanatory. My hypothesis for this is because Mike is so advanced in his statistics knowledge, it's probably less simple for him to explain basic statistics to a class of people who don't know much. This critique is not a big deal or a character assessment of what Mike is capable of -- it's just a small critique. But the overwhelming majority of the class seems to hate Mike for simply being given an impossible task and wanting us to learn R, which he was tasked with doing.

Strength: very helpful, creating a great environment to learn, trying to do his best 
Weakness: materials taught in class is not well connected with what we were examed

Mike Wininger is absolutely awesome. Phenomenally Smart, helpful to the max, and just overall a very cool guy. I really mean it. He did what he could to bring life to the content, and he truly made difficult to understand concepts more accessible and interesting. I hope to have other courses with him at Yale.
Please see above. The instructor was effective in smaller settings, but seemed resistant to feedback during the first half of the course.

Dr. Wininger was an excellent instructor, who encouraged us to think critically and challenged us in a way that I hoped all Yale instructors would challenge me. There will be a lot of negative feed back from students who most likely are straight from undergrad. In talking with these students it was clear that they either wanted an easy Honors, a spoon fed experience, or they didn't want to be challenged. I have no negative comments about Professor Wininger.
Great resources provided to students.
See above

A strength is that Dr. Wininger did attempt to understand and assist his students in whatever way that he could. I believe that most of the problems that arose in the course stemmed from his shifting in teaching and testing styles. In the future, I believe that it would be easier for most students to adapt to his teaching style if he were to remain more consistent throughout the course of the semester.

Dr. Wininger is a very well-intentioned instructor. He made his best efforts to improve the course throughout the semester (especially following constructive feedback), and I highly appreciate his flexibility. He also provided students with many resources and made himself available for assistance. However, his teaching style just wasn't for me. The course, especially at the beginning, was very unorganized. Towards the end of the semester, he started providing lab primers, lecture roadmaps, and slide notes that I found very helpful.

strength: provided materials to study and allowed for recorded lectures 
weakness: literally everything else, poorly written and administered tests, perpetuate problematic views throughout the course, never account for own fault as instructors
He did not seem interested in supporting students. He was not very receptive to complaints.

I think the Professor means well and is a nice person but overall unfit to teach an introductory level biostatistics course. This is a difficult course to teach, and I think the Professor would be better suited to teach a higher level statistics course.

the teacher is helpful and passion about his students. course would be improved if he could teach more systematically and comprehensively instead of asking us to go through the book by ourselves and just mention some important points in class

This instructor seemed like a really intelligent statistician, but he was the worst teacher or instructor I have ever had to date. It is a shame that this professor was unable to teach coherently, because I am sure that he has a lot of knowledge that he could share if he was a better instructor. Some of his weakness are that he seems to have difficulty empathizing with students that are not looking to be statisticians, and that he blamed the students for their inability to learn, rather than being introspective about his teaching abilities and style. His strengths were that he was willing to reach out to students individually if they were failing or falling behind, but if he had the ability to teach well to the majority of his students, this singular kindness would not have been necessary. Many students who stopped attending class started doing better on exams and felt like they understood the material better than when they had been attending class, which is really sad. We deserve to be taught something in a course when we are paying to receive a Yale degree. It is ridiculous that I had to teach myself the entirety of a class when a professor was being paid to teach and not doing so.

Mike was very understanding and open to critique. He tried to be accommodating to students in any way that he could by adjusting his lecture style to fit the needs of the class, giving extra credit to make up for class concerns over grades, etc.

Strength: Mike was very passionate in teaching, always really encouraging and tried hard to make the class livelier.
Weakness: answered too many questions (which might not be all totally useful or relavent) in class rather than teaching. More on the end of entertaining students that knew already the materials and excel in class than teaching generally.

Heart in the right place. Needed to establish boundaries earlier in class. DEFINITELY not as bad as everyone is going to say he is. I think he just got overwhelmed with the, frankly, unreasonable expectations of graduate students who only wanted the answer without having to think about it.

Professor Wininger is a supportive and fair professor. On several occasions, he has provided me with useful feedback during times I was struggling. I also very much appreciated how he worked with students to accommodate us when unforeseen events came up such as sicknesses and other personal difficulties. He is a kind professor, and he created a positive learning atmosphere. However, I wish he had covered more of the R material in lectures. I would have been a little less lost during labs.

Michael is a really positive and encouraging tutor, and we could tell he really cares and thinks much about teaching. But it might because it's my first year here, it is a little difficult for me to catch up with his explanation and examples in class. I would prefer reading books to give myself an answer. The handwriting in lectures is not that readable as well. However, we tell that he prepares every course carefully and upload all the materials that we might use in class or after class, and all media of his lessons, his lectures, notes, homework and solutions. So I still think he really cares about our learning and have done a great job.
Deflected any criticisms of his teaching onto poor work ethic of students.

Prof. Wininger was very understanding and I thought tried to help each student to the best of his abilities. I didnt agree with some of his teaching tactics as the beginning on the semester but he really progressed as the semester went on. This included clarity in his PowerPoint presentations as well as giving good outlines for test preparations etc.

Strengths: Interactive, knowledgeable
Weakness: Hard to navigate the material given it was his first time teaching the course.

Mike's efforts as a professor were and are incredible - he was incredibly responsive, caring, transparent, and very responsive to feedback. However, lectures continued to be disjointed and lacking in direction. I wish there had been more connection between the material and real application to public health. 

I wish Mike had walked through how to do some problems with us, rather than just pull up notes and go through his notes. 

I think Mike would be a great professor for an advanced biostatistics/statistics course - I think too many students in the class, including myself, lacked the background needed to understand and/or do well in this class. I also think the class size itself was much too big. 

well-intentioned, good person, but not the right professor.

sweet guy but terrible lecturer, often felt more like a comedy sketch than productive learning time
was also a fair evaluator but the class was made tough by his poor lectures

Mike did a good job at providing feedback and adapting as the course progressed. I think that he was strong in understanding the topics and explaining them. I think it was a tough class to teach due to differences in mathematical ability. It could be a better class by separating it into a beginners vs. intermediate/advanced statistics class.
He is a nice person and his enthusiasm was contagious. But maybe Mike didn't have much experience, the class schedule was not that good and some important concepts were not illustrated.
Extremely responsive to the needs and learning styles of students, which is a tall order In of itself.

Very dedicated to teaching the material and creating various activities to reinforce the material taught. However, did not seem to appreciate the limits on our time given the demands of our other coursework. In the future, I would suggest designing the course so that the material is taught and reinforced without requiring several additional exercises. Epidemiology, is an example of a similar type of course whose teaching style was more manageable.

Dr. Wininger does care about his students and wanted us to succeed, and I do not think he was being malicious when he allowed us to do poorly, but I do think it was a failure on his part and he was resistant to criticism for a while. I had a particular problem where I was given a failing grade on a lab I thought I did well in. When I forwarded the issue to him, Dr. Wininger was great about staying up late on a weekend to go over my work and get me a response. The problem was that instead of telling me where I went wrong, he, in so many words, told me I was gravely behind my peers, that I showed several red flags and lack of understanding, and several other personal notes and assumptions about my performance as opposed to telling me where I went wrong. When I reviewed with my TF it turns out my code was off because of a simple typo. And yet, unprompted, Dr. Wininger continued to contact me for weeks with comments and unkind references to my shortcomings, I believe in an attempt to gaslight me and make me feel as though I was less intelligent than I was to avoid responsibility for his poor grading practice. Either way, his policy is valid, but he did not need to defend himself and his TA through devaluing me. Because of this experience I avoided him and avoided reaching out for help out of fear of being insulted again. His kneejerk reaction to our poor performance on the second exam, where he instead posted all of our canvas data on when we accessed the data as an explanation for poor performance, seemed also to avoid responsibility. What I can praise are the changes he made the levels to which he made himself available for reviews and office hours for the next exam so we could all improve. His teaching and attitude greatly improved and we all really appreciated it, however it was not enough to save the class.
Instructor was likable and gave strong effort in preparing class materials

Dr. Wininger was extremely positive and optimistic in his approach to teaching. However, I don't think he fully realized that all students had varying familiarity with statistics and experiencing in using R. He clearly put a lot of time and effort into designing the course schedule, labs, and homeworks, but it was all overlooked and underappreciated because a foundation of understanding in using R was not really built in this class. Codes were mentioned very briefly in class and sometimes tested out in labs, but it generally felt as though I still didn't understand the basic language of R and what I was doing most of the time. He did, however, do a decent job of teaching the stats material (items from the textbook).

Dr. Wininger is a delightful person, and I really appreciate that he wanted each of us to do our best and genuinely cared that we understood the course materials. He could improve by using a different program for showing notes-- the program used in class was very small and difficult to read, even when sitting in the front of the class.
Its a core class requirement that will require you to use R software in labs and conceptual learning from the textbook.

I would not because it was very disorganized and I didn't like having to poke around for information only to get thrown off in an exam. I wish the material was presented better and in a more organized, logical way.

It's mandatory, so not really a recomendation but I would say practice and engage with R outside of class. Like Mike said, if you'd don't open it more than once a week or have a natural ability for it, you will find it difficult, particularly at first.
Yes, I think it's a necessary skill and am glad we had to take it.
Good
This course was mediocre. Only take it if you have to or want to learn R.

Basic Biostatistics. Really good knowledge.
Professor is an R expert. Will be able to do basic things in R at least at the end of it.
Overall my favourite part would just be the labs because that's where I learned the most.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student.
Overall, I would say that it was not a good class and I had to teach myself a lot of the material. I did come away with a better understanding of stats and R and the end, though.

The importance of data collection in the work force has become more and more apparent. Important concepts in biostatistics are covered and I highly recommend taking this course. The professor is engaging, but the organization of the course was poor.
Doable, just keep up with work. Learn R early.
It's very elementary, worth taking as a prerequisite of other stats classes.

This is a challenging, but rewarding, course. It's truly a course that you need to apply yourself in and keep up with the material throughout the semester. However, if you stay on top of your work you will be able to grasp complex concepts and apply your knowledge to coding and problem-solving.
Run away. Fast. Would not recommend. If you want to spend 10x as much time on a course and get nothing out of it, only then would I recommend.
Hard, but worthwhile. Wouldn't recommend it if it wasn't required. Not really a class to take for fun.

I would recommend this class to other students only after fundamental changes were implemented regarding its structure and how core pillars of the field are taught and explained. A different classroom would be extremely helpful as well. Though 47 College Street is new, it is NOT conducive to effective learning, unfortunately.
It is hard but if you keep up with things you will learn very useful skills that will help you in the real world.

I think I would recommend it toanother student. Because it's a very useful and necessary course and can learn about how to use R. But I think this course may be difficult for those who don't have relative knowledge background.
Good skills, but felt like was thrown into learning a new language
Required. Get through, it builds character.

This course is great! No matter what department you're in, you will need to know these concepts to work in public health (and many other sectors). The course does a great job teaching the basics of coding in R as well as the basics in statistical concepts. It is a lot of work but rewarding in the end to truly understand the concepts which we will surely see again.
Good, yes

summary: unnecessarily tough, frustrating, and too much work for no reason at all. class is usually of no use to actually understand and learn concepts.
this is a mandatory course so students have to take it- i would suggest a diff style of teaching than this
As the course stands, incorporating R the way it was incorporate,  I would not recommend this course.

Difficult class that you will have to spend a lot of time on to do well.  Content can be disorganized and its stressful to follow.  Professor is very smart so if youre interested in deeper understanding of content, Mike W is your guy.  This class is meant for no stats background, but a background in stats/programming would have been very useful.
Well, it's required. So they have to take it.
Very disorganized and poorly taught! I would definitely NOT recommend this to anybody.
required
Absolutely not. I did not learn a thing in this class and feel sorry for anyone who will have to take this class. This class was an unorganized mess.

This course provided a broad introduction to biostatistics. It is required for first year MPH students in all disciplines. I do recommend this course to other students as it provides an overview of concepts that will likely be useful to biostatisticians and public health grads through our careers.
The course is required, but I would warn another student not to be phased by the tricky questions and to have confidence.

I would recommend only following major reconstruction of the course. Statistics and R are crucial skills to the field and should absolutely be learned at some point. This class made meeting these goal very difficult.
No I would not recommend this course
Waste of time and money. Did not learn anything. Would not recommend to anyone ever.

This course will give you a solid foundation of statistics and will introduce you to the statistical program R. I would recommend this course to another student because it will help prepare you for a career in public health while also giving you marketable skills.
I would not recommend this course unless changes are made to its structure.

I could not recommend the course enough. My main piece of advice, which is tough for some people, would be to deeply engage with the material. The course is set up for one to succeed, but it really is up to the student to put in the work to get the outcome they desire. I think the course and professor Wininger are amazing, and YSPH can only benefit from the course existing and growing as it is.
The course content needs to be adapted to be more practice-based and the labs need to be changed entirely in order for this to be effective.

Summarize: You learn stats and you learn R and you learn how you can use your knowledge in each domain to better inform your knowledge in the other. It may seem like two separate entities at first, but you quickly learn that success in this course is paramount on integrating the two. I'd recommend it to any student wanting to get foundational knowledge in statistics and pick up a coding language. It is well structured and facilitates learning through many office hours, a lab hour each week along with over 100 pages of notes/optional homeworks+solutions/slides to guide you.

This course is a great introduction to biostatistics. It's so satisfying to read articles and have a deeper understanding of the methods/results now that I know about concepts like linear regression, various hypothesis tests, etc. Hiccups aside, this course enhanced my leaning of statistics and will continue to deepen my understanding of public health research methods as I continue at YSPH.
I would definitely recommend. It is useful and really helpful for anyone wanting to gain an understanding of statistics.

As the class currently operates, yes, I would recommend. However, I would not have recommended the class at the beginning of the semester. Many improvements were made and the course was eventually brought up to par.
It's a class everyone should take because statistics are generally important in any field. I would recommend this to another student if some of the curriculum was fixed.
I will recommend this course to students who have never learned R before. This course is a very good start for new learners. However, students need to be  prepared for the heavy workload each week.
Course is chaotic and a disservice to students. It is a mandatory core but if at all possible should be avoided.
This is a course that have been given an overhaul by a new professor. It is useful and you will learn, but you will largely be teaching yourself.

Overall I really enjoyed this course and learned a lot about R and how to manipulate my data with R. The major weakness with this course is the organization of lab and introduction of R, but otherwise it is very comparable to previous stats classes I have taken.

Biostat is not a walk in the park. The subject matter itself is never "easy", so everyone should expect to put in a lot of work. The course will give you an introduction to a lot of important and helpful concepts. Learning R is fun as the skillset is helpful for future job prospects. The book is very helpful -- it was my primary study source for the semester. Labs were fun and useful - I actually got to build R skills. Homework is another helpful resource too to build R skills though not essential to study for exams. The professor is very helpful in office hours than in lectures, so if you are confused about something, go to his office hours. Be sure to stay on top of your material every week because it is very easy to fall behind in this class, and once exams are around the corner, things start to add up and it can be very overwhelming. So, do the readings, get on top of the materials, seek out for help if needed, pace yourself, manage your time well, and you'll be fine.

This course covers a ton of useful concepts that will be applicable in other courses and future careers. There is crossover within other courses like Epidemiology, micro economics, and even accounting/valuation.
Don't take it if you can help it. This is not like any biostats course you've taken before, it's difficult to learn everything together no matter how hard you work.

This course will rarely teach you anything about biostatistics in the classroom. Unless you have the time to commit to studying on your own for multiple hours a week, as well as referencing OTHER university's materials like BU. You will have a difficult time with this material, if you do not have any background or experience in this field. I would NOT recommend this to another student, because I feel like I learned little to nothing, and stressed the entire semester.
You learn a lot of valuable information but mostly by reading through the book and figuring it out yourself.
This course focuses primarily on biostatistics theory with a bit of practical application through its labs, which make use of R statistical software.
I really enjoyed the subject. I think there were some things that can be improved, but overall, I feel that I've gained very valuable skills.
The course is necessary for public health. It is a lot of work, but looking back I am proud of how far I came.
i would recommend this course for sure. it is challenging but that does not make it a bad course. it challenged many of us to think outside the box and put us out of our comfort zone.

The material is very important subject that is needed to learn for public health work so in that sense I would recommended the class. However, the class could still be greatly improved. Professor Wininger made moderation's throughout the semester to improve performance but more work could be done to improve the course.
Id say its a typical intro stats course with practical R coding skills attached. If you pay attention and read the textbook youll do just fine.

The course concepts were great and I think an introductory biostats course with a language component is great for learning conceptually but also gaining a skill to be used in the working world. I think if the class was set up another way with more structure and consistency throughout I would recommend it more.
Valuable information but you have to be responsible for your own learning. I would recommend because the skills learned are already helping me
This course is an intensive into to R and and overview of the basics of biostatistics in public health.
This course introduced basic data science. However, for students already with the knowledge of basic data analysis, it may not provide more information.

This course provides basic understanding in biostatistics and R. At the end of the course you will be able to understand basic concepts and apply that knowledge to a variety of settings.

I think a basic understanding of biostats is important, but I think this course needs to be improved before I would recommend it to another student.
No.  Take a normal statistics course and teach yourself R ... or take an R class later.  This class felt too fragmented to really have mastered statistics.
-I would recommend this class once changes to lab were made
It is an essential course to your public health degree. Take it with Mike!
This course is mandatory for all non-Biostatistics stream MPH students so there is not much of a choice. If it were a choice and I knew what I know about the course now, I would never have taken it.

I would not recommend this design of the class. Biostats itself is an important subject and worth teaching, but I think the design must be different. For a course like health policy, I think it's worth having a giant cohort of people hear Jason Schwartz's lectures, as that is helpful to anyone. For biostats, I don't think the same class size works. In all, if the design were more personalized to upper and lower division stats (or something to this effect), it would help everyone involved.
Overall, the lab is great, learned a lot from my TA. But maybe not recommend to another student, sometimes not answering/explaining the questions very well.

This was perhaps the hardest course Ive ever taken in my life. It was also amongst the most rewarding. Part of this has to do with me returning to graduate school after an 8 year period of time since undergrad. Regardless, Im particularly happy that I learned about this content. I feel it was the most valuable content I learned about, hands down, and I think itll prove very useful as a hard skill in the job market.
Great introduction to stats and R, I would highly recommend this to every student.
Would probably recommend just because Biostatistics and R material is important and interesting, but would recommend to take with different professor and lab instructor...

I would not recommend this course with the same professor. While the material was easy enough to understand, the way that we were presented the information was so stressful and nonsensical that the classes' motivation plummeted.
I think with some changes, the course will be very beneficial to future students. I would not recommend the course in its current format.
no, opt for another smaller course with better teaching and where you utilize more software programming
This course is useful if you want to learn how to use R.
This is a tough course and requires work but can be manageable provided the right instruction and guidance - suggest taking with another professor.
it is worthy and helpful even for students who have basic knowledge about stats and R before. it would help them to have a better understanding of the stuffs.

This course was an absolute nightmare. If there is any possibility you could avoid taking it, do so at all costs. I do not recommend this class at all. It was the most stressful and frustrating class I have ever taken.
This course requires you to read the textbook to be successful in the class and be more independent in learning math.

Improvements/changes was constantly make in class as the instructor was new. However, course was still disorganized and as an introductory course, it should have provided a more solid foundation for students or it would be very difficult for students to apply relates skills in the future.

I would recommend this to a student who has had little to no prior experience in biostatistics and needs foundational knowledge. I would also recommend it to a student who wants to begin learning how to code in R for social science research purposes.
This is a basis for epidemiology. Whether or not you like it, you have to like it.
I would not recommend it, but it is not like you have a choice.

Overall I probably would not recommend this class for someone who wants to take an intro for a biostatistics course. I felt the material was too scrambled and there was to much emphasis on r and not on the foundations of statistics.
The course covered the important aspects of an introductory biostatistics course and is useful for students looking to develop their statistical skills using the R coding environment.

I would not recommend this course to students who want to learn biostatistics or statistics. I would encourage them to wait for another professor/for the class to be redesigned. This course was incomprehensible despite the many hours of work I put in on my own, with classmates, the professor, and TFs. This course design really needs to be reviewed. The lectures and lab sections have nothing to do with each other.
required, so yes, but also it's pretty good course in general. I feel much more employable after this semester (in conjunction with epi) than I have with four years of undergrad

This class was an incredibly basic class if you have taken statistics courses prior and any student can achieve a passing grade with a bit of work. As well, you will get a comprehensive view of R and how it applies to concepts. Mike truly cares about his students and wants everyone to succeed. However, if you feel strongly about math and have a bit of a math background, this class is a bit too basic to take if you only need to learn R.

This is a basic class for data analysis. Although this class has some disadvantages, I believe the enthusiasm of Mike could overcome it and this course could be better in the future. It's also a good way to learn basic R skills. So I recommend it.

Yes, especially given the carefully  line-by-line R programming instruction written by the professor that is a rare find in this arena. (Again, I only have my undergraduate  institution Dartmouth College for comparison here. )

Very good but very time-consuming course, with an unrealistic investment of time required to truly understand/master the material. Participating as much as possible in terms of reading, quizzes, lab assignments etc pays significant dividends later on when time becomes more of a premium commodity.

I am frustrated because I was looking very forward to learning R for professional growth and feel as if I learned nothing. I would encourage the administration to listen to what was discussed in the group session where people recommended teaching R in R labs and having our testing on R be extended projects instead of rushed labs and handwritten code on exams. I would not recommend that it be taught in at all the same format or method. I will probably find it unfair that next years students will receive a higher quality education for the same money and will receive better grades for less work but they do not deserve to go through we went through. This class took away from my performance in more important classes and in the end I only came out knowing what I could teach myself from a book.

I would recommend the course as the material is important foundational knowledge to continue on in epidemiology. I feel that a restructuring of the course is necessary, however, to create a more consistent theme between in-class and out-of-class learning.

I would only recommend this course if it is absolutely required for a student. Dr. Wininger is potentially a great instructor and knowing to how to use R is a valuable skill - but this class was a mess.
